description: Explore the diverse worlds within our Solar System and how they formed.

slides.title: What is Planetary Science?
slides.content:
# Study of Worlds ü™ê

Planetary science (planetology) studies planets, moons, and planetary systems.

It combines astronomy, geology, and atmospheric science to understand how these bodies form and evolve.

slides.title: Solar System Formation
slides.content:
# The Nebular Hypothesis üå™Ô∏è

1. A giant cloud of gas/dust collapsed under gravity.
2. Formed a spinning disk.
3. Sun formed in the center (99.8% of mass).
4. Dust clumped into planetesimals $\to$ protoplanets $\to$ planets.

slides.title: Terrestrial Planets
slides.content:
# The Rocky Worlds ü™®

Inner planets: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars.
- composed primarily of rock and metal.
- Solid surfaces.
- Few or no moons.
- No ring systems.

slides.title: Gas Giants
slides.content:
# The Big Ones üéà

Jupiter and Saturn.
- Massive composition of Hydrogen and Helium.
- No solid surface (you'd sink until crushed).
- Many moons and rings.

slides.title: Ice Giants
slides.content:
# The Cold Ones ‚ùÑÔ∏è

Uranus and Neptune.
- Composed of "ices" (water, ammonia, methane) over a rocky core.
- Methane gives them their blue color.
- Very cold and windy.

slides.title: Planet Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which of these is NOT a Terrestrial planet?

slides.title: Dwarf Planets
slides.content:
# Pluto and Friends üê∂

Defined by IAU in 2006:
1. Orbits the Sun.
2. Information spherical shape.
3. Has NOT cleared its orbit of debris.

Examples: Pluto, Eris, Haumea, Ceres.

slides.title: Moons
slides.content:
# Natural Satellites üåô

- **Ganymede** (Jupiter): Largest moon, has a magnetic field.
- **Titan** (Saturn): Has a thick atmosphere and liquid methane lakes.
- **Europa** (Jupiter): Subsurface ocean of water (Life?).
- **Io** (Jupiter): Most volcanic body in the solar system.

slides.title: Asteroids
slides.content:
# Space Rocks ü™®

Rocky remnants from the early solar system.
- Most found in the **Asteroid Belt** between Mars and Jupiter.
- Can be piles of rubble or solid iron.
- Potential threat of impact (Dinosaur killer).

slides.title: Comets
slides.content:
# Dirty Snowballs ‚òÑÔ∏è

Ice and dust from the outer solar system (**Kuiper Belt** and **Oort Cloud**).
- When near the Sun, ice sublimates creating a **Coma** (atmosphere) and **Tail**.
- Tail always points away from the Sun (Solar wind).

slides.title: Meteoroids
slides.content:
# Falling Rocks üå†

- **Meteoroid**: In space.
- **Meteor**: Burning up in atmosphere (Shooting star).
- **Meteorite**: Hits the ground.

Most burn up completely.

slides.title: Kepler's First Law
slides.content:
# The Law of Ellipses ü•ö

Planets happen to move in **Elliptical** orbits with the Sun at one focus.
- NOT perfect circles.
- **Perihelion**: Closest point to Sun.
- **Aphelion**: Farthest point.

slides.title: Kepler's Second Law
slides.content:
# Equal Areas üçï

A line connecting a planet to the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal times.
- Meaning: Planets move **faster** when closer to the Sun and **slower** when farther away.

slides.title: Kepler's Third Law
slides.content:
# The Harmony Law üé∂

The square of the orbital period ($T$) is proportional to the cube of the semi-major axis ($a$).

$$T^2 \propto a^3$$

Distant planets take much longer to orbit (Neptune takes 165 Earth years).

slides.title: Orbit Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: According to Kepler, when does Earth move fastest?

slides.title: Planetary Atmospheres
slides.content:
# Thin Blue Lines ‚òÅÔ∏è

- **Mercury**: None.
- **Venus**: Thick $CO_2$. Runaway greenhouse effect (465¬∞C).
- **Mars**: Thin $CO_2$. Cold.
- **Titan**: Nitrogen/Methane.
Gases are retained by gravity vs temperature.

slides.title: Magnetospheres
slides.content:
# Force Fields üõ°Ô∏è

Generated by churning molten metal cores (Dynamo effect).
- Protects planet from Solar Wind (charged particles). 
- Creates Aurora (Northern Lights).
- Earth has a strong one; Mars lost its one.

slides.title: Impact Cratering
slides.content:
# Scars ü§ï

The dominant geological process in the solar system.
- Craters tell us the age of a surface.
- Many craters = Old surface (Moon).
- Few craters = Young/Active surface (Earth/Io/Europa).

slides.title: Planetary Science Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- **Formation**: Gas cloud collapse.
- **Types**: Rocky, Gas, Ice, Dwarf.
- **Motion**: Kepler's Laws govern orbits.
- **Geology**: Atmospheres, Magnetism, and Impacts shape worlds.
